div.head: 12.11.1881 Samstag
div.p: This morning we started for the choir expedition. We went down to London by the 8.45 train and got there about 9. We directly took 2 busses and drove to the Houses of Parliament but finding that they were not yet open we went in to Westminster Abbey where we heard the beginning of the morning service. Then we went back to the houses of Parliament and were let in by the Victoria tower. The rooms were splendid, decorated with frescos, gilding, woodcarving and other ornaments. We first came to the queens Victoria I. robing room in which there is a very fine throne. We then went through various smaller rooms and at last came to the where we saw another very fine throne. All the seats are covered with red leather. then we were taken through various passages decorated with beautiful frescoes to the house of Commons which looks very mean after the house of Lords. We there saw the bar by which Bradlaugh had been stopped the last time he tried to enter the house by force. Then we went into a law court where Lord Coleridge was sitting. Bradlaugh was also there. He looked very fat and mean and altogether disgusting. We afterwards went into some more law courts and into the court of exchequers where rather an amusing case. about forgeing a signature, was going on. Westminster hall struck me as being a very fine place. We afterwards went down the Thames to London-bridge in the same boat as Gladstone. We then saw a chrysanthemum show said to be the finest in the world; some of the chrysanthemum were very pretty. We also bought some tortoises and other reptiles at Greens in Covent Garden. We had a very good dinner a 2/ a head at the Horse Shoe hotel. Then we walked to the Prince of Wales’ theatre and saw the „Colonel“ Burnand which takes the aesthetes off beautifully. After the Colonel we went to Madame Tussauds and saw the wax works. I was quite taken in by a wax policeman. We then drove for to a chemists where we ordered some Sodium and some potash for experiments; then we drove to Waterloo station and took the train to Ascot where we arrived at about 10.30. Those of the choir who are in the first div. (I included) went down to the terrapyn pool house and put the animals we had bought at Green’s into and round about it and afterwards had some „negus“ and went to bed. We posted a letter, to Mackenzie, signed Eliza WicksVon den Schülern erfundene Person. who is supposed to be an old friend of his mothers. He firmly believes in her.
